message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of heavy rain on the stability of a hill. Torrential downpours can cause excessive erosion and saturation of the soil, leading to instability in the hillside. This makes the hillside prone to landslides or slope failures, making it unstable. Option (A) is incorrect because while erosion may cause the hillside to change in shape, it does not become "depressed" in the sense of becoming sad. Option (B) is unrelated because the hardness of rocks does not change due to rain. Option (C) is incorrect because while rainfall can promote growth of vegetation, it does not necessarily make the hillside "greener," as it depends on the existing plant species and their response to water.

This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of torrential downpours on the environment. When there is a torrential downpour, the excess water can saturate the soil on the side of a hill, making it unstable and more prone to landslides or erosion. Option (A) is incorrect because the hill does not become depressed. Option (B) is incorrect because the excessive water does not make the hill rock hard. Option (C) is incorrect because while the increased moisture may facilitate growth, it does not directly make the hill greener.
